metadata.title: Novel synthesis of nano needle-like Cu2O-GO-TiO2 and CuO-GO-TiO2 for the high photocatalytic performance of anionic and cationic pollutants

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Solid State Sciences
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ssscie
Novel synthesis of nano needle-like Cu2O-GO-TiO2 and CuO-GO-TiO2 for the high photocatalytic performance of anionic and cationic pollutants
Jingjing Zhaoa, Dinh Cung Tien Nguyenb, Yonrapach Areerobb, Won-Chun Ohb,∗
a College of Chemical Engineering, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing, 100029, China bDepartment of Advanced Materials Science & Engineering, Hanseo University, Seosan-si, Chungnam, 356-706, South Korea
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nano needle-like Self-assembly Organic contaminant photodegradation Graphene oxide nanocomposite
A B S T R A C T
Novel nano needle-like Cu2O-GO-TiO2 (Cu2OGT-A) and CuO–GO-TiO2 (CuOGT-B) composites with superior photocatalysis were successfully synthesized via a self-assembly process at a low temperature. The structural and morphological characterizations of the synthesized compounds were analyzed using a series of analytical techniques. The photocatalyst showed excellent activity under visible light and was used for the photodegradation of safranine O (SO), reactive black B (RBB), and gallic acid (GA) as target anionic and cationic pollutants. The removal capacity of CuOGT-B is slightly higher than that of Cu2OGT-A, and the removal rates of SO, RBB, and GA reach up to 82.91%, 81.51%, and 83.87%, respectively. Furthermore, the excellent morphologies of Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B composites, e.g., needle-like structure, monodisperse, and graphene sheets drastically improve their dispersion in solution, light harvesting, charge separation and transportation, which might do some contributions to improve their photocatalytic activities accordingly. The Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B prepared under the conditions reported herein could be promising materials in water purification.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, the increase of serious environmental pollution has demanded more attention. The visible-light responsive photocatalyst for degradation of organic pollutants has been favored by many environmentalists and has been widely used in environmental treatments [1]. GO-based metal-oxide hybrid materials have outstanding properties suitable for a variety of areas such as energy and the environment. Graphene oxide has been successfully decorated with numerous inorganic materials including gold, ZnO, TiO2, and Cu salts using various methods, producing nanocomposites with photocatalytic activity for the degradation of pollutants [2]. As a good solid-state electron mediator, graphene oxide (GO) prompts the rapid transfer of photogenerated electrons from the inorganic semiconductor to GO and thereby reduces the electron-hole recombination rate [3].
Cu-based catalysts have been widely applied because they are inexpensive, non-toxic, and have unique features such as high solar absorbency and high electron communication. Cu2O and CuO are important p-type transition metal oxides with a narrow band gap of 2.17eV and 1.2eV, respectively, and have thus been investigated for a variety of applications such as sensors, photocatalysis, and energy storage. Moreover, One-dimensional (1D) nanostructures such as wires, rods, belts and needle provide unique thermal, mechanical, electronic,
optoelectronic, and optical properties and have become an area of intensive research. It is well-known that the shape of the material affects to the phytochemical properties of the material. For instance, singlecrystalline 1D nanostructures (nano needle) are supposed to be significantly stronger than their larger dimension counterparts due to a reduction in the number of defects per unit length. Therefore, Cu nano needle like shape has been considered as a promising nanomaterial for a photocatalyst, which found that no research has been previously reported. Most recently, CuO and its hybrid materials have been proven to be effective photocatalysts for the degradation of rhodamine B(RhB) and 4-nitrophenol under UV–VIS irradiation [4,5]. Sun et al. reported a simple method of synthesizing a Cu2O/GO/TiO2 that increased the photodegradation of methylene blue under visible light irradiation [6].
On the one hand, TiO2 has been the most popular candidate of semiconductor-oxides/graphene-oxide composites because of its high oxidizing capacity, low cost, high chemical stability, and non-toxicity toward humans and the environment. However, spherical TiO2 nanoparticles with a small surface area can easily agglomerate; they therefore demonstrate poor interfacial contact with GO. Finally, TiO2 with a wide band gap (3.0–3.2 eV), rapid recombination of the photogenerated electron (eCB−) and hole (hVB+) pairs, low quantum efficiency, and low response to visible light (less than 5%) significantly restrict its practical applications [7]. To overcome these drawbacks of TiO2, and to improve

its property, the combination of TiO2 with other semiconductor-oxides is urgently needed. Therefore, TiO2 combined with CuO extends the excitation wavelength of TiO2 from ultraviolet to the visible region [8]. The composite accelerates the separation of the photo-generated electron–hole pairs. Cu2O, CuO, and GO play important roles in improving the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 [6]. Furthermore, the TiO2 coupled semiconductor is essential as it provides a maximum interfacial contact with the GO surface without aggregation, which is a necessary feature for increasing the photocatalytic performance. It is believed that the incorporation of multidimensional inorganic particles may prevent the aggregation of GO sheets with a higher surface area and pore volume. The GO sheets can effectively stabilize inorganic nanoparticles to prevent their aggregation [9], and the properties of the nanoparticles could be enhanced by anchoring them onto GO sheets. Thus, it will be advantageous to use the cooperative effect of metal ion doping such as Cu2O, CuO, and TiO2 on the surface of GO mesostructured materials for enhancement of visible-light absorption response and photocatalytic activity.
On the other hand, CuO nanostructure composites with various morphologies, including rod-like, urchin-like, cocoon-shaped, dandelion-like, leaf-like, flower-like and frost-like morphologies, have been successfully obtained using a series of synthetic methods [10–14]. Cu2O
nanostructure composites of different morphologies, including corallike, shuriken-like, pod-like, and rose-like morphologies have been successfully obtained [15–18]. In these methods, glucose and hydrazine were used as reducing agents [19,20]. From these results reported in the literature, it was found that expensive template, toxic reducing agents, high reaction temperatures and pressures, as well as long reaction times are often needed in order to obtain morphology controllable nanostructures of Cu2O.
In this work, a novel nano needle-like Cu2O-GO-TiO2 and CuO-GOTiO2 photocatalysts were prepared by a simple, inexpensive, timesaving and environmentally benign method. During the self-assembly step, Cu (II) acetate, NaOH, and triethylamine (TEA) were used as precursors for the synthesis of novel nano needle-like Cu2O-GO-TiO2 and CuO-GOTiO2 without the need to use the templates and the toxic reducing agents at room temperature. Different alkali sources have specific influences on the morphology and properties of nanocomposites. The possible mechanism for the photodegradation towards these model water pollutants was also explored. This materials is promising with excellent photocatalytic properties and can be effectively used for industrial textile dye degradation processes.

sections.heading: 2.1. Reagents
sections.text: Graphite powder, Copper (II) acetate (Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, 95%) and safranine O (SO, C20H19ClN4) were purchased from Samchun Pure Chemicals Co. Ltd., Korea. Reactive Black B 95% (RBB) was purchased from JAY Chemical Industries Limited, India. Gallic acid (GA,C7H6O5,98%) was purchased from Samsung chemical Co. Ltd., Korea. Titanium (IV) n-butoxide (TNB, Ti(OBu)4, C16H36O4Ti) as a titanium source was purchased from Kanto Chemical Co., Tokyo, Japan. Ethanol (C2H5OH, 95%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, (93.0–100) %), and hydrochloric acid (HCl, (35.0–37.0) %) were purchased from Duskan Pure Chemicals Co. Ltd., Korea. Triethylamine (TEA, ≥99.5%) was purchased from Junsei Chemical Co., Ltd., Japan. All the chemicals were used without further purification and all experiments were carried out using distilled water.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Synthesis of the nano needle-like Cu2O-GO and CuO–GO composites
sections.text:
The GO was prepared according to the Hummer-Offerman method.
The GO (0.1 g) was dispersed in 40mL deionized (DI) water and sonicated for 1 h, followed by the addition of 2mmol Cu(CH3COO)2 as the copper source and 20mL NaOH 1M as the alkaline source under strong magnetic stirring at room temperature (25 °C) for 1 h, and then obtained the Cu2O-GO. Another sample was prepared using 7mmol TEA instead of NaOH, and all other experimental conditions were kept constant. The obtained precipitates were washed with distilled water 3 times and 95% ethanol twice to reach a neutral pH and were then dried in an oven at 90 °C for 24 h. The nano needle-like Cu2O or CuO combined oxidized graphene (Cu2OG-A) and (CuOG-B) composites were obtained.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Synthesis of the nano needle like Cu2O-GO-TiO2 and CuO–GO-TiO2 composites
sections.text:
To obtain TiO2, 0.008mol urea was dissolved in 40mL ethanol, and 0.5 mL acid acetic and 2mL Ti(OBu)4 were then added dropwise to the above solution. The as-prepared solution was continuously stirred at 80 °C for 10min before being transferred to an autoclave for the hydrothermal treatment at 150 °C for 18 h. The mixture was filtered and washed with distilled water several times. The anatase TiO2(2mmol) was added to the above reaction system under strong magnetic stirring at room temperature (25 °C) for 1 h 30min. Another sample was prepared using 7mmol TEA instead of NaOH, and all other experimental conditions were kept constant. The obtained products were washed with distilled water 3 times and 95% ethanol twice and then dried in an oven at 90 °C for 24 h. The brown nano needle-like Cu2O–GO-TiO2 (Cu2OGT-A) and black CuO–GO-TiO2 (CuOGT-B) were obtained. The preparation procedure is shown in Fig. 1.
The source of Cu2O and CuO was formed by copper (II) acetate with the alkaline source generated by NaOH or TEA. If CH3COO− is a reducing agent in the alkali source A, then the Cu2+ ions are reduced to Cu+ ions. Self-oxidation reduction reactions possibly occur under NaOH conditions [21]. In a wet chemical route, for the self-assembly of Cu2O or CuO, it can be deduced that primary crystals generate due to the electrostatic force of the exposed surface planes of the primary crystals. Since the surface charges of Cu2+ and GO are opposite, an electrostatic attraction is expected to induce the coprecipitation. If Cu2+ is strongly adsorbed by the rich oxygen-containing functional group on the surface of GO, then the Cu2+ is reduced to Cu+ ions loading on the surface of GO. CuO-B has been found to evolve via an intermediate step from Cu(OH)2, and has been found to exhibit self-
assembled micro architectures of primary entities. In the nucleation process, copper hydroxide would first appear as small crystal nuclei on the surface of GO, with subsequent crystal growth from the nuclei to form nano needles. Cu(OH)2 nano needles are first formed on the surface of GO. The nano needles self-assemble into nanoribbons and then into cross-bundles of Cu(OH)2. Cu(OH)2 structures then dehydrate into CuO structures [22]. Cu2O(CuO) created via the above process covers the GO surface to form the respective composites. However, this conflicts with previous findings that suggested the synthesis of Cu2O-GO or CuO-GO nanostructures requires temperatures in the range 100–180 °C [21,23,24]. NaOH is a very strong base which reacts quickly with acetate, whereby as the reaction rate increases, the crystal nucleates more rapidly, with a much smaller grain size. On the other hand, TEA is a weak base, and the slow reaction rates with acetate render a slow growth process from seeds to larger crystals.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text:
X-ray power diffraction (XRD) data were analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer (SHIMADZU XRD-6000) equipped with a Cu Ka X-ray source (1.5406 Å). The shape and structure of the nanomaterial surface were analyzed at high-resolution by SEM (JSM-5600 JEOL, Japan). The chemical composition was detected using an energy dispersive X-ray (EDS) analysis incorporated with the SEM. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Hitachi HT7700, operated at 100 kV) was used to analyze the morphology of the samples. High-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HRTEM) images of the samples were obtained on a Hitachi H9500 operated at 300 kV. The surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the prepared nanocomposites were determined from the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barret-Joyyner-Halender (BJH) methods. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a KRATOS AXIS SUPRA with a monochromatized Al Ka X-ray source (10 kV, 1500W, pass energy= 40 eV). UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) analysis was conducted by the ultraviolet–visible (UV–Vis) spectrophotometer (SHIMADZU UV-2600) ranging from 200 to 800 nm. The band-gap energies of the photocatalysts were calculated by applying a modified Kubelka–Munk function from UV–Vis DRS data. Raman spectroscopy was performed using a Confocal-Raman imaging system with a 633 nm laser for excitation (Renishaw in Via Reflex). Photoluminescence spectra (PL) were
measured using a Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature with an excitation wavelength of 360 nm.

sections.heading: 2.4. Photocatalytic degradation activity
sections.text:
The degradation of organic pollutants was processed in two stages: absorption and photocatalytic degradation. First, the adsorption/desorption equilibrium of organic dyes was established in a dark box for 120min. Then, the photocatalytic degradation experiment of the dye solutions was conducted under visible light irradiation with different irradiation times (from 0 to 180min). The safranine O (SO), reactive black B (RBB), and gallic acid (GA) were chosen as the model anionic
and cationic pollutants to test the photocatalytic degradation efficiencies of the as-prepared catalysts. SO is a well-known cationic fluorescent dye. RBB is azo dyes. GA is one kind of polyphenol. An Xe lamp was provided by an 8-W lamp with a cut-off filter (λ≥ 420 nm) was used to generate visible light at a distance of 10 cm from the solution surface at room temperature. In each experiment, appropriate amounts of as-prepared samples (0.05 g) and SO solution (100mL, 5.0×10−4 mol/L) were extracted and placed in a 150mL quartz photoreactor and continuously stirred magnetically before and during
the irradiation experiments. In order to achieve complete adsorptiondesorption equilibrium, the suspension was magnetically stirred in the dark for 2 h before irradiation. During the photocatalytic degradation tests, 3 mL of reaction solution was withdrawn every 30min, and the concentration was analyzed by measuring the absorbance of the solution on a UV–vis spectrometer at 520 nm. The photocatalysts were removed using a centrifuge machine at 10,000 rpm for 15min before the analysis. The measurements of the photocatalytic degradation of RBB and GA were the same as those of SO, except for the absorption wavelength measurements. UV–visible spectrophotometric analysis was performed on each sample of the pollutant solutions at regular time intervals, during which the absorbance spectrum was obtained. Spectrophotometric analysis was performed on each sample of the pollutant solutions at regular time intervals during which the absorbance spectrum was obtained. The spectral ranges for SO, RBB, and GA were investigated from 450 nm to 600 nm, from 400 nm to 700 nm, and from 700 nm to 1100 nm, respectively, using a calibration curve since no reaction occurred with the absorption of products at these wavelengths.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization
sections.text:
Fig. 2 presents the XRD patterns of the Cu2O–GO, CuO–GO, Cu2O–GO-TiO2, and CuO–GO-TiO2 nano needle composites. Six characteristic peaks of Cu2O-A can be found at 2θ=29.68°, 36.48°, 42.44°, 61.52°, 73.66°, and 77.54°, corresponding to the (110), (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) crystal planes of a single cubic phase (JCPDS No.05-0667), respectively [6,25]. The characteristic peaks of CuO-B can be found at 2θ=32.70°, 35.64°, 38.84°, 48.90°, 53.65°, 58.34°, 61.64°, 66.22°, 68.06°, 72.48°,75.56°, and 83.20°corresponding to the (110), (−111)/(200), (200)/(111), (202), (020), (202), (113), (311), (220), (221), (004) and (222). crystal faces of the monoclinic structure (JCPDS No.72-0679), respectively [26]. The characteristic peaks of TiO2 can be found at 2θ=25.72°, 48.82°, and 55.06° corresponding to (101), (200), and (105) overlapped with (211) crystal planes of anatase structure (JCPDS No. 21-1272), respectively [27]. The presence of very sharp peaks in the XRD patterns of Cu2O, CuO, and TiO2 indicates the good crystal quality of the particles. Moreover, no characteristic peaks assigned to impurities such as Cu(OH)2 or CuO were detected in Cu2OGA and Cu2OGT-A; no characteristic peaks assigned to impurities such as Cu(OH)2 or Cu2O were detected in CuOG-B and CuOGT-B. The single cubic phase Cu2O, monoclinic CuO, and anatase TiO2 diffraction peaks occur clearly and simultaneously in the XRD patterns of Cu2OG-A, Cu2OGT-A, CuOG-B, and CuOGT-B, which prove the successful synthesis of Cu2O-GO-TiO2 and CuO-GO-TiO2 in nanocomposites. Due to their weakness, the diffraction peaks of GO cannot be found relative to the strong diffraction peaks of Cu2O, CuO, and TiO2 which was possibly related to the low content and crystallinity of GO in the obtained samples [6,27]. The existence of GO in the composites could be confirmed by Raman and TEM results shown in later studies [9,28].
The crystallite size was estimated using the XRD patterns using the full width at the half maximum of a peak and Debye-Scherrer equation as depicted in equation.
=d Kλ β θ/ cos (1)
where d is the crystallite size, K is dimensionless shape factor (here taken to be 0.94), λ is the wavelength of X-ray used and β is the full width at half maximum corresponding to the Bragg's angle θ. Based on XRD, average particle sizes of Cu2O and CuO are 5 and 10 nm respectively.
The morphology of the Cu2O(CuO) and TiO2 nanocomposites on the GO surface were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) in Fig. 3 and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Moreover, the mass ratios of C, O, Cu, and Ti in Cu2OG-A, Cu2OGT-A, CuOG-B, and CuOGTB, respectively, are validated by elemental diffraction analysis (EDS) and are presented in Fig. 4 and Table 1. As shown in SEM images (Fig. 3(a) and (d)), the pure spherical Cu2O or CuO particles are easy to aggregate. It was difficult to clearly distinguish between the Cu2O (CuO) and TiO2 shapes. To further characterize the nanocomposites, analysis of the TEM images was carried out. As shown in Fig. 5, the general microstructures of the nanocomposites are observed. The TEM images in Fig. 5 clearly show that the surface of the plate-like GO sheets was uniformly covered with the nano needle-like Cu2O(CuO) and dotlike TiO2 mixture. TiO2 and Cu2O(CuO) have a good particle dispersion on the GO surface, which is an essential factor for improving the photocatalytic performance. The nano needle structure is clearly displayed, and the average sizes of the nanocomposites range from 200 to 400 nm (length). Fig. 6 reveals that a single Cu2O or CuO is assembled from dozens of columnar nanocrystals with an average width of 5–7 nm. The HRTEM image of a single nano needle shown in Fig. 6 indicates spacings of 0.21 nm and 0.25 nm between the two adjacent lattice planes of a nano needle, corresponding to the (200) lattice planes of Cu2O and the (002) lattice planes of CuO, confirming that Cu2O and CuO have been successfully introduced on the surface of the GO film.
The BET specific surface areas and pore parameters of the samples are summarized in Table 2. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm results of the Cu2OG-A and Cu2OGT-A nanocomposites clearly exhibit similar type II curves (Fig. 7(a)). On the other hand, the CuOG-B
and CuOGT-B nanocomposites have small hysteresis similar to that shown in the type IV curves (Fig. 7(a)). It is speculated that the nano needle has a mesoporous structure [29]. The pore sizes of Cu2OG-A calculated using the BJH method and the BET-specific surface area were
about 4.22 nm and 72.83m2/g, respectively. These values are larger than the theoretical value of 33m2/g for pure Cu2O nanowires [20]. The specific surface area (BET) of Cu2OGT-A is higher (228.72 m2/g) than that of CuOGT-B (119.99m2/g). This is because the Cu2OG-A grain size decreases and its specific surface area increases. The BJH pore size distribution plots for the N2-sorption isothermals of the nanocomposites are shown in Fig. 7(b). It can be seen that the main pore size distributions of both CuOG-B and CuOGT-B are located at about (30–45) nm, which represents a narrow size distribution. As the surface areas of the nanocomposites increase, the nanopore size and pore volume lead to better photocatalytic ability under visible light.
Fig. 8(a) shows the full range of XPS spectra corresponding to C 1s at (283–289) eV, O 1s at (528–535) eV, Cu 2p at (930–964) eV, and Ti 2p at (456–466) eV, confirming the presence of the Cu2O, CuO, and TiO2 loading on GO. The high-resolution spectrum of each electron element is plotted in Fig. 8(a)–(e). The binding energy peaks of C 1s at 284 eV are ascribed to the non-oxygenated C (C]C/CeC) in aromatic rings, while a weak peak at 288 eV are ascribed to the epoxy group of CeOeC, the carboxyl group of C]O and −OeC]O, and the new bonding between CuO and GO such as the CueOeC bonds [27]. The peaks located at (934 and 954) eV in Fig. 8(d) are ascribed to the Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 binding energies of Cu2O, respectively [25,27]. The peaks located at (932 and 952) eV are ascribed to the Cu2p 3/2 and Cu2p 1/2 peaks of CuO, respectively. The shake-up peaks as satellite peaks at approximately (942 and 962) eV indicate the presence of an unfilled Cu 3d9 shell and reconfirm the presence of Cu+ or Cu2+ in the
tested nanocomposite [30]. The binding-energy value of Ti 2p3/2 is 464 eV and that of Ti 2p1/2 is 458 eV, which match well with the titanium (IV) species. The O 1s spectra located at (529.5, 531, and 533) eV are ascribed to the metal oxide peaks appear at 529.5 eV, Lattice oxygen comes around 531 eV, and metal hydroxide peaks comes at 533 eV (hydroxide probably moisture adsorbed on the material surface) respectively. The difference in peak intensities between the O 1s, as shown in Fig. 8(c), implies a new bonding between Cu2O(CuO) and GO
such as the CueOeC bonds. In addition, the different binding energies of the similar signal peaks indicate the new chemical bonds in the Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B nanocomposite.
The UV–vis spectra of the prepared samples are displayed in Fig. 9. For comparison with the UV–vis spectra of pure TiO2, the absorption edges of Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B are apparently shifted to visible light with more absorption, indicating the narrowing band of TiO2. These results indicate that the modification of TiO2 with GO and Cu2O is helpful to improve the visible light response of TiO2. Compared to Cu2OGT-A, the absorption intensity of CuOGT-B is stronger in the visible light region [6,31]. The band gap energies of these photocatalysts can be estimated by Eq. (1):
= −ahv A hv E( )g 1 2 (1)
where α, h, ν, and Eg are the absorption coefficient, planck constant,
light frequency, and band gap, respectively. The band gaps (Eg) [which were estimated from the extrapolated values of the tangents on the wavelength axis to the plots of (αhν) ½ versus hν (Fig. 9)], were (1.98, 3.11, 2.24, and 2.91) eV for Cu2OG-A, Cu2OGT-A, CuOG-B, and CuOGTB, respectively. TiO2 has a band-gap energy of 3.2eV in anatase phase [32]. TiO2 was improved by its combination with cupric oxide and GO, thus reducing the band-gap energy more than in pure TiO2. As has been demonstrated, when a narrower band-gap energy leads to a much broader absorption in the region of visible light and produces more electron–hole pairs, better photocatalysis is generated [6].
Fig. 10 represents the Raman spectra of GO, Cu2OGT-A, and CuOGTB. Raman peaks corresponding to the anatase TiO2 can be observed at (149,395, 512, and 636) cm−1. The Raman spectra of Cu2O display three typical peaks at (293, 342, and 585) cm−1. The Raman spectra of CuO are located at 295 cm−1, while TiO2 is located at the other peaks [25,31,33]. The intensity of the peaks of TiO2 and GO are stronger than those of Cu2O and CuO. A typical Raman spectrum of GO exhibits two main bands: D band (1335 cm−1) and G band (1598 cm−1). This further confirms the presence of GO [34]. These results are fairly consistent with the XRD and XPS results.
Photoluminescence (PL) spectra are used to study the efficiency of the charge carrier trapping, immigration, and transfer of semiconductors, revealing the recombination of the photo-generated electron (eCB−)-hole (hVB+) pairs in the semiconductors. Fig. 11 shows that the PL signal peak at 418 nm of Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B decreases compared to that of Cu2OG-A and CuOG-B, indicating the incorporation of TiO2 leads to a decrease of the recombination rate in the nanocomposites. Since the PL signal peak at 418 nm of CuOGT-B is much weaker than that of the other nanocomposites. CuOGT-B shows the least charge recombination rate and thus probably leads to enhance the photocatalytic activity in the visible light region [31]. The decrease of the recombination rate mainly results from the sufficient interfacial contact between CuO and TiO2. Briefly, the photogenerated electrons in the excited TiO2 are transferred to CuO immediately after photoproduction, separating the photogenerated electrons and holes, and efficiently inhibiting their recombination.

sections.heading: 3.2. Photocatalytic degradation activity
sections.text:
The results of the adsorptive and photocatalytic effects of the previously prepared Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B evaluated by different organic pollutants such as SO, RBB, and GA are described in this section. The percentage of concentration (Ct/C0) from the variation of absorbance at the specific wavelength of model pollutants is adopted to evaluate the degree of pollutant photodegradation. The photodegradation efficiency η( %) is calculated as
= − ×η% (C C )/C 100%0 t 0 (2)
where C0 is the initial concentration of the model pollutants and Ct is the concentration of the remanence of the model pollutants.
Fig. 12 (a), (c) and (e) and Table 3 show the adsorption and photocatalytic degradation curves of the relative concentration (Ct/Co) and time (t). At the adsorption/desorption equilibrium stage, the curves increase steeply. After 120min adsorption/desorption equilibrium in dark box, the CuOGT-B retained the highest adsorption capacity of 64.81, 59.25 and 66.07% for SO, RBB and GA solution as anionic and cationic pollutants. Meanwhile, the adsorption capacity for Cu2OGT-A were 51.92, 45.81 and 52.67% respectively. The CuOGT-B composite has a greater adsorption capability than that of the Cu2OGT-A composite because the surface area of CuOGT-B (98.04 m2/g) is larger than that of Cu2OGT-A (72.83m2/g).
When the visible light is irradiated, photodegradation curve increase relatively slowly with the increase of irradiation time. The degradation efficiency decreased as the irradiation time increased. After three hours of irradiation, CuOGT-B still has higher pollutant removal rates of SO, RBB, and GA than Cu2OGT-A. The removal rates of CuOGTB for SO, RBB, and GA are 82.91, 81.51 and 83.87% respectively, whereas for Cu2OGT-A, the removal rates are lower, with SO, RBB, and GA at 63.78, 62.98 and 65.06%, respectively.
The removal rate has also been well reported by Nguyen et al. They reported that the adsorption capacity of CuO-GO and CuO-GO-TiO2 can achieve about 50% for the solution of RBB, which are higher than that of P25 and CuO-TiO2 composites (about 0.82 and 20 respectively). Under visible irradiation for 180min, the highest photodegradation effect of CuO-GO-TiO2 can retain 74.51%, which is higher than that of P25, CuO-TiO2 and CuO-GO (5.41, 54.31 and 67.98%, respectively) [26].
The degradation rate constant of the catalytic reactions can be obtained using the first-order kinetic equation,
− =C C k tln ( / ) ·t app0 (3)
where kapp is the reaction rate constant (min−1). The value of kapp indicates the photocatalytic degradation activity of the nanocomposites. The kapp for different nanocomposites can be acquired by plotting -ln (Ct/C0) versus t, obtaining the kapp values from the slopes of the graphs.
As illustrated in Fig. 13, the plots of -ln (Ct/Co) against the irradiation time (t) are nearly linear, and thus fit well with the first-order kinetics with high values of regression coefficients (R2 > 0.952). The pollutant photocatalytic degradation capacity of CuOGT-B is slightly higher than that of Cu2OGT-A under the same conditions. Tables 4 and 5 summarizes the apparent rate constants of the different pollutants and photocatalysts. For both Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B, the photodegradation of RBB dye is higher than that of the other two pollutants, SO and GA. The apparent rate constants (kapp) has also been well reported by
Nguyen et al. They reported that the apparent rate constants from high to low are 4.0×10−3 min−1(CuO-GO-TiO2),3.4× 10−3 min−1 (CuOGO) and 3.2× 10−3 min−1(CuO-TiO2) [26].
These data revealed that CuOGT-B is a new potential catalyst for high photodegradation activity. The above results indicate that the excellent photocatalytic activity of the CuOGT-B is attributed to the following factors.
(1) A narrower band-gap energy of CuOGT-B that leads to much broader absorption in the region of visible light results in an enhanced photocatalysis [35].
(2) The p–n heterojunction is composed of CuOGT-B. The VB of TiO2(+2.9 eV) is more anodic than that of CuO (+2.16 eV), while the CB of CuO (+0.46 eV) is more negative than that of TiO2 (−0.29 eV) [33], allowing the injection of the photogenerated electrons from the TiO2 to the valence band (VB) of CuO, which facilitates the separation of charge carriers. Meanwhile, the photoinduced holes of TiO2 could shift to that of TiO2, and then shift to the GO surface to join the reduction reaction (e−CB). The photogenerated holes of CuO can also switch to the GO surface to participate in oxidation reactions (h+VB) [26]. As a good solid-state electron mediator, GO prompts the rapid transfer of photogenerated electrons between CuO and TiO2, which results in charge separation and stabilization, thus reducing the recombination process [27].
(3) The optical and electronic properties of these porous materials are strongly influenced by the high specific surface areas and pore volumes of the materials, which have a more catalytic active site at the nanoscale dimension. The porous compounds attract considerable interest for their strong ability to adsorb and interact with pollutant atoms, ions, and molecules on their wide interior surface and in the nanometer pore size. The porous structure with high specific surface area which improves contact between nanocomposites and organic pollutants and increases the surface adsorption of water and hydroxyl groups, water, and hydroxyl can react with the light hole of the catalyst to generate a hydroxyl free radical, which is a strong oxidizer of the degradation of organic pollutants.
It has been reported that the superior photocatalysis of the preprepared nanocomposites might result from the formation of more oxyradicals (O2−, HO·) because of the enhanced electrons (eCB−) and holes (h+VB) separation and a larger specific surface area provided by the porous CuOGT-B. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this study, a novel nano needle-like Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B with high specific surface areas were successfully synthesized via a self-assembly process at room temperature. The advantages of the preparation method include simplicity, cost effectiveness, short time, and low temperature; it thus has a promising future for environmental applications. The CuO and TiO2 loading to GO were confirmed by XRD patterns, SEM, TEM, BET, XPS, and Raman spectra. The CuOGT-B has a stronger photocatalysis than Cu2OGT-A under visible light irradiations, suggesting a synergism between the CuO, GO, and TiO2. The high photocatalytic degradation activity is attributed to the suitable band gap of CuOGT-B, which increases the light absorbance in the range of visible light. It is also attributed to the high specific surface area of the p-n nanocomposites that serve as electron traps and facilitate the separation of charge carriers. The modification of copper oxide and GO on TiO2 can further enhance the photocatalytic performance of TiO2 and promote the application of TiO2 in the photocatalytic field.

metadata.abstractText: Novel nano needle-like Cu2O-GO-TiO2 (Cu2OGT-A) and CuO–GO-TiO2 (CuOGT-B) composites with superior photocatalysis were successfully synthesized via a self-assembly process at a low temperature. The structural and morphological characterizations of the synthesized compounds were analyzed using a series of analytical techniques. The photocatalyst showed excellent activity under visible light and was used for the photodegradation of safranine O (SO), reactive black B (RBB), and gallic acid (GA) as target anionic and cationic pollutants. The removal capacity of CuOGT-B is slightly higher than that of Cu2OGT-A, and the removal rates of SO, RBB, and GA reach up to 82.91%, 81.51%, and 83.87%, respectively. Furthermore, the excellent morphologies of Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B composites, e.g., needle-like structure, monodisperse, and graphene sheets drastically improve their dispersion in solution, light harvesting, charge separation and transportation, which might do some contributions to improve their photocatalytic activities accordingly. The Cu2OGT-A and CuOGT-B prepared under the conditions reported herein could be promising materials in water purification.
